text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has changed her team of financial managers and appointed Naveed Qamar and Moeen Afzal as federal minister for finance and secretary finance respectively.
- Ex-captain of the army Arshad Jamil was executed for killing nine villagers near Hyderabad.
- Demand for oil products is expected to shoot up from 15 million tonnes per annum to 26 million tonnes by 2000.
- Pakistan will need to produce up to 23 million tonnes of wheat by 2005 to meet food requirements.
- All Pakistan Textile Mills Association chairman Javed Saifullah said there is a need for the import of one million bales of cotton in 1996/97 (July-June) due to expected lower output of cotton.
- "Cutting down the inflation and budget deficit and arranging more inputs from the private sector, would be my first priority," said new Finance Minister Naveed Qamar, who took over on Monday.
- Short supply of tractors has adversely affected the cultivation of wheat and cotton crops.
- Fiscal incentives will not be provided to any company to be located outside the export processing zone.
- Jamaat-i-Islami called off its sit-in after protesters reached parliament following daylong clashes with police.

- Interior Minister Naseerullah Babar said Jamaat-i-Islami chief Qazi Hussain Ahmed and his second in command Professor Ghafoor had been release soon after their arrest to avoid a backlash from their supporters.

- Afghan General Abdul Rashid Dostum for the first time directly accused Pakistan of backing the Taleban, evoking a quick response from Interior Minister Naseerullah Babar who demanded concrete proof of Islamabad's involvement.
- Newly-appointed Finance Minister Naveed Qamar and other high-ranking officials will hold a formal meeting with the International Monetary Fund negotiators today.
